item.title: Mass Grave Site With 440 Bodies Found in Izium, Ukraine Says
item.description: Investigators and prosecutors were dispatched to the site on Friday, just days after President Volodymyr Zelensky raised a flag over the reclaimed city.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents waiting for humanitarian aid and meals in the recently recaptured town of Balakliya, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Princess Anne’s Influence, and Workload, Rises in a Slimmed-Down Royal Family
item.description: Often appearing at more than 400 events a year, Anne is likely to become even more central as a trusted adviser to her brother, the king.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Princess Anne at Balmoral Castle, in Scotland, on Saturday.

item.title: Rise of Far-Right Party in Sweden Was Both Expected and Shocking
item.description: The Sweden Democrats, with roots in neo-Nazism, came in second in national elections and will have a powerful influence on a new center-right government.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Stefan Jerrevång/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “If we are going to support a government that we’re not sitting in, it’s going to cost,” Jimmie Akesson, leader of the Sweden Democrats, said before the election on Sunday.

item.title: In Central Asia’s ‘Great Game,’ China Seeks the Advantage
item.description: Xi Jinping’s visit to Central Asia this week sheds a light on his country’s efforts to increase its sway in the vast, resource-rich region once considered Russia’s domain.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Kazakhstan Presidential Press Office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, arriving in Kazakhstan on Wednesday as part of his first trip outside China since the pandemic started.

item.title: 5 Russian Bullets Dashed an Opera Singer’s Dreams. Then He Reclaimed His Voice.
item.description: While on a rescue mission in Ukraine, Sergiy Ivanchuk was shot in the lungs, apparently ending his chance at opera stardom. His recovery is a marvel of medicine, chance and his own spirit.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergiy Ivanchuk, a Ukrainian opera singer, spent months in the hospital after he was shot trying to save civilians fleeing Kharkiv.

item.title: Floods in Italy Leave at Least 9 Dead
item.description: The downpour was the latest in a summer of extreme weather events. Streets were turned into rivers, bridges and highways were blocked, and thousands were left without power.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Flash flooding on the Sanguerone River in Sassoferrato, central Italy, on Friday.

item.title: Thousands Join ‘The Queue’ to See Queen Elizabeth Lying in State
item.description: Thousands of people waited in line — a very long line — to pay homage at the coffin of the queen, who will lie in state until her funeral on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line to see Queen Elizabeth II lying in state in London crossed the River Thames and snaked for miles along the South Bank.

item.title: A Detailed Rundown of Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral Day
item.description: On Monday, dignitaries from across the globe will bid farewell to the queen at a service in Westminster Abbey.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II has been lying in state at Westminster Hall since Wednesday afternoon.

item.title: Putin Nods to Xi’s ‘Concerns’ on Ukraine War
item.description: The discordant messages of China’s president, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested that despite an earlier pledge of “friendship,” Moscow does not have an unconditional ally in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: In a photograph released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China meeting in Uzbekistan, on Thursday.

item.title: Attempt to Kill Argentina’s Vice President Fuels Conspiracy Theories
item.description: An assassination attempt against Argentina’s vice president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, failed. Now many Argentines believe the entire event was a hoax.
item.dc:creator: David Feliba, Natalie Alcoba and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti in support of Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner on Independence Avenue in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Marvel Attracts Criticism With Israeli “Captain America” Superhero
item.description: The studio has angered many Palestinians and their supporters by casting the actress Shira Haas to play Sabra, a mutant Mossad agent, in a “Captain America” movie.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Shira Haas in New York in 2021. She gained international recognition for her roles in the Netflix series “Unorthodox” and “Shtisel.”

item.title: Giorgia Meloni May Lead Italy, and Europe Is Worried
item.description: The hard-right leader has excoriated the European Union in the past, and she regularly blasts illegal immigration and George Soros. But she is closer than ever to becoming prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni, center, who would be the first woman to lead Italy, posed for a photograph with a supporter in Cagliari, Sardinia, this month.

item.title: U.K. Health Ministry Wants No Oxford Commas. Period.
item.description: The directive discourages the use of the contentious grammatical device, and also encourages employees to be “positive” and to avoid “jargon.”
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Tributes to NHS staff outside King’s College hospital in London this summer.

item.title: The ‘Queue’ to View Queen Elizabeth’s Coffin Closes Temporarily
item.description: The British government said it would turn people away for a period of at least six hours after the volume of those waiting reached capacity.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line along the Thames on Thursday. The estimated wait time for those who had scraped through before the cutoff was 14 hours.

item.title: Profiting in Congress
item.description: Dozens of lawmakers trade stocks related to their work, and it’s harming trust in the government.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Congress can buy and sell stocks with few restrictions.

item.title: At Old Coal Mines, the American Chestnut Tries for a Comeback
item.description: Across Appalachia, scientists and foresters are trying to reintroduce a hybrid version, helping to revive damaged land while also bringing back a beloved tree.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao and Maddie McGarvey

item.title: ‘At the Breaking Point’: Tibetans, Under Lockdown, Make Rare Cries for Help
item.description: China’s ever-tightening Covid rules have prompted public complaints from residents of areas usually intimidated into keeping quiet.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A socially distanced line, background, of people waiting for Covid tests in Lhasa, the capital of Tibet.

item.title: Cultural Cringe and ‘The Lost City of Melbourne’
item.description: A new documentary goes some way to explaining why the city looks the way it does.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A view of the city square in Melbourne in 1970.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A meeting between Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin, left, listens as Chinese President Xi Jinping makes remarks at their meeting Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Will Send $600 Million in Military Supplies to Ukraine
item.description: The new shipment continues the Pentagon’s recent trend of sending ammunition that Ukraine needs to carry out heavy fighting in the country’s south, east and northeast.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A multiple rocket-launching vehicle being transported by a Ukrainian military vehicle in June.

item.title: In ‘Cancer Alley,’ Judge Blocks Huge Petrochemical Plant
item.description: The company, an affiliate of Formosa Plastics, said it intended to move forward with the $9.4 billion complex in St. James Parish despite the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Reserve, La. Reserve is in St. John the Baptist Parish, which abuts St. James Parish in “Cancer Alley,” where the plastics plant would have been built.

item.title: Putin’s admission of Chinese concerns about Ukraine isn’t a sign of a weakening bond, U.S. officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.media:description: In this combination of pictures, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, meeting with Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, in Uzbekistan at a summit on Thursday.

item.title: The E.U.’s top official meets with Zelensky.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Francis: Arming Ukraine Can Be ‘Morally Acceptable'
item.description: The pontiff said that it is acceptable for countries to provide weapons to Ukraine so that the country can defend itself, but stressed that communication channels with Russia should remain open.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis spoke to reporters after attending an interfaith conference in Kazakhstan this week.

item.title: Biden to Meet With Families of Griner and Paul Whelan
item.description: The fates of both Americans have been complicated by the deteriorating diplomatic relationship between the United States and Russia over President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The Putin-Xi Summit
item.description: Plus Europe’s tilt to the right continues, and Roger Federer is retiring.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, on Thursday.

item.title: A mass grave site with 440 bodies was found in Izium, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: William Lamb
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: European Union Signals a Move Away from Wood Energy
item.description: Wood was supposed to help the E.U. reach its renewable energy goals. But it has contributed to increased emissions and a loss of Europe’s protected woodlands.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A forest near Bialowieza, Poland, in 2019.

item.title: Mexico Arrests Army General Linked to Disappearance of 43 Students
item.description: A top military officer suspected of ordering the killing of at least six of the students who disappeared in 2014 has been arrested, the latest in a string of high-profile arrests.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: A memorial to the 43 missing students in Mexico City last month.

item.title: Germany Announces Holocaust Reparations and Fund for Ukraine
item.description: The country will pay $1.2 billion, including emergency aid for Holocaust survivors in Ukraine and, for the first time, remembrance education.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Gideon Taylor, president of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, spoke on Thursday at a commemorative event 70 years after the Luxembourg Agreement in Berlin.

item.title: Britain Has a New King. The Swans Have a New Owner.
item.description: Thanks to a centuries-old law, the country’s monarch also happens to be the owner of its population of mute swans.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: David Barber has served for nearly 30 years as the royal swan marker, a sort of swan ambassador responsible for keeping track of the population during an annual count called the “swan upping.”

item.title: Biden Issues New Order to Block Chinese Investment in Technology in the U.S.
item.description: The move, which is bound to heighten tensions with Beijing, reflects growing unease about China’s ability to access the personal information that Americans hand over to mobile apps and other services.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A humanoid robot at the Consumer Electronics Show in January in Las Vegas. President Biden’s order is significant for microelectronics, artificial intelligence, biotechnology and more.

item.title: Russia Damages a Dam in Ukraine, Sparking Flooding Fears
item.description: The attack sent millions of gallons of water gushing downstream and officials said a catastrophe had been narrowly avoided.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The damaged dam after a missile strike, outside Kryvyi Rih, on Thursday.

item.title: What is Putin hoping for from Xi?
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy, Keith Bradsher and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Start of construction of the China-Russia East Route natural gas pipeline, also known as the Power of Siberia trunk pipeline, in Heihe in northeastern China’s Heilongjiang Province, in 2015.

item.title: The Fog of San Francisco
item.description: It’s a life force, with an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: John Branch
item.media:credit: Nina Riggio for The New York Times

item.title: Zelensky Is Involved in a Car Accident but Isn’t Seriously Hurt
item.description: Ukraine’s president did not mention the accident during his nightly address.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky made an unannounced visit to the recaptured city of Izium on Wednesday.

item.title: Solar Energy Is Helping Schools Make Ends Meet
item.description: Public schools are increasingly using savings from solar energy to upgrade facilities, help their communities, and give teachers raises — often with no cost to taxpayers.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times

item.title: Woman Is Arrested in South Korea Over Deaths of 2 Children in New Zealand
item.description: The children’s bodies were found in suitcases that had been in a storage facility, said the New Zealand police, who are seeking the woman’s extradition on murder charges.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Dean Purcell/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police investigators at the scene in Auckland, New Zealand, where two children’s bodies were discovered in suitcases last month.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Zelensky at the front.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Izium on Wednesday.

item.title: Prosecutor Who Sought to Use Evidence Derived From Torture Leaves Cole Case
item.description: The Biden administration had adopted a policy excluding all evidence obtained through torture; the prosecutor argued the law allowed it.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Cole was bombed off the coast of Yemen in October 2000. The bombing trial has resulted in a dispute over evidence that prosecutors obtained through torture.

item.title: Zelensky Visits a City Just Miles From the Front, Underscoring Ukraine’s Gains
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky’s trip to a city reclaimed days ago demonstrated Ukraine’s growing boldness in the wake of Russia’s frantic retreat from the country’s northeast.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made an unannounced visit to Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, on Wednesday, where Russian forces had retreated about a week earlier.

item.title: The State Department warned private citizens not to negotiate prisoner swaps with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: A State Department spokesman was asked on Wednesday about a report that Bill Richardson, a former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, met with Russian officials in Moscow this week.

item.title: In Russian Border City of Belgorod, the Ukraine War Feels Real
item.description: In Belgorod, 25 miles from Ukraine, recent losses by Russia’s military have brought home the reality of the war in a way not present elsewhere in the country.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: In Belgorod, Russia, military vehicles marked with the letters Z, V and O, which have become symbols of the Russian invasion, ride through the city.

item.title: President Biden will nominate Lynne M. Tracy, a career diplomat, to be ambassador to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Lynne M. Tracy accepted an award for heroism in 2009 from Hillary Clinton, then secretary of state, a year after Ms. Tracy’s car was attacked by militants while she was serving in Peshawar, Pakistan.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Pakistan, Submerged
item.description: Plus Volodymyr Zelensky visits a reclaimed city and the downfall of Malaysia’s former prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amira, 15, center, is helped by her husband through water on the edge of the town of Johi. She had given birth just a few days before.

item.title: An Eastern City Under Attack Wonders How Far Ukraine’s Offensive Can Go
item.description: Bakhmut residents who have endured relentless shelling by the Russians watch the Ukrainian forces’ recent victories and weigh whether to stay or to flee.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: A tank passing through the center of Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Sweden’s Far Right Just Made History. Is It the Country’s Future?
item.description: The anti-immigration Sweden Democrats beat out more moderate right-wing parties in a country famed for liberal governance. It is the latest example of the right’s staying power across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Jimmie Akesson, the leader of the far-right Sweden Democrats party, at a gathering in Stockholm on Sunday.

item.title: Patagonia Founder Gives Away the Company to Fight Climate Change
item.description: Yvon Chouinard has forfeited ownership of the company he founded 49 years ago. The profits will now be used to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Natalie Behring for The New York Times

item.title: Oil Executives Privately Contradicted Public Statements on Climate, Files Show
item.description: The documents, subpoenaed in a House investigation of climate disinformation, show company leaders contravening industry commitments.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: A Shell station in Houston. An internal email in 2020 said the company’s announcement of a pathway to net zero emissions had “nothing to do with” its business plans.

item.title: Queen’s Coffin Passes Through London Landmarks to Westminster Hall
item.description: King Charles III, his siblings and his sons followed the gun carriage carrying the monarch to Westminster Hall, where she will lie in state.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The procession was one of the most solemn of the public rituals marking the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Russia Damages a Dam in Ukraine, Sparking Flooding Fears
item.description: Pedestrian bridges were washed away and water rose along river banks in the city of Kryvyi Rih in southern Ukraine, where Kyiv’s forces are carrying out a counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian missile attack on a dam caused flooding in the industrial city of Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Dramatic Shift, Right-Wing Bloc Wins Slim Majority in Sweden
item.description: Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson said on Wednesday that she would resign. Despite the success of the far-right Sweden Democrats, they will influence but are not expected to be formally part of the governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Fredrik Sandberg/TT News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The new government is expected to be led by Ulf Kristersson, head of the Moderates, part of a right-wing bloc that won 176 of 349 seats in Parliament.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II Will Be Buried at Windsor Castle
item.description: The queen will be buried alongside her husband and royal predecessors in St. George’s Chapel.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Flower tributes are moved to the grounds within the gates on The Long Walk, in front of Windsor Castle on Tuesday.

item.title: Top E.U. Official Is Becoming an Unexpected Wartime Leader
item.description: In her annual address, Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, pushed for the bloc to remain firm in the face of Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, addressing the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, on Wednesday.

item.title: France Will Keep a Cap on Gas and Power Price Hikes in 2023
item.description: Élisabeth Borne, the prime minister, said the cap was far below the 120 percent hike that was expected without any government intervention as prices soar, exacerbated by the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Nuclear plants in France provide about 70 percent of the country’s electricity. Even though they are currently plagued by technical issues, France does not expect widespread energy blackouts over the winter.

item.title: E.U. Calls for Taxes and Handouts to Battle Rising Energy Prices
item.description: The European Commission wants the bloc’s members to impose taxes on the profits of energy companies to fund handouts to households and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Transmission lines outside Lyon, France. The European Commission has proposed a series of emergency measures as it grapples with spiraling energy prices stoked by the conflict in Ukraine.

item.title: Who Will Pay for Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral
item.description: The state will cover the huge price tag at a time when many in Britain are struggling to pay their bills and are bracing for a difficult winter.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The cost of Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral has not yet been made public.

item.title: Pakistan Suffers Record Flooding, Turning Villages Into Islands
item.description: The flooding has displaced more than 33 million people, submerging vast areas of Pakistan that are likely to take months to dry out.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boat operators from other regions have come to Sindh Province to make money as ferries for stranded townspeople. They use power lines as landmarks.
